\n<p>要想继续嗯哼&nbsp;PyQt4:</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><span class=\"n\">brew</span> <span class=\"n\">tap</span> <span class=\"n\">cartr</span><span class=\"o\">/</span><span class=\"n\">qt4</span>\n<span class=\"n\">brew</span> <span class=\"n\">tap</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">pin</span> <span class=\"n\">cartr</span><span class=\"o\">/</span><span class=\"n\">xr</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">x</span>  <span class=\"mi\">1</span> <span class=\"n\">zoomq</span>  <span class=\"n\">staff</span>  <span class=\"mi\">66</span>  <span class=\"mi\">8</span>  <span class=\"mi\">8</span> <span class=\"mi\">21</span><span class=\"o\">:</span><span class=\"mi\">50</span> <span class=\"n\">PyQt4</span> <span class=\"o\">/</span><span class=\"n\">pyqt</span><span class=\"err\">@</span><span class=\"mi\">4</span><span class=\"o\">/</span><span class=\"mf\">4.12</span><span class=\"n\">_1</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">packages</span><span class=\"o\">/</span><span class=\"n\">PyQt4</span><span class=\"o\">/</span>\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>是的, 要在 pyenv 中使用 brew 安装的 pyqt&nbsp;得:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>在对应版本环境的 site-packages 中使用 <code>ln -s</code> 关联到系统环境的库</li> \n <li>就 Qt 而言要链接两个东西: \n  <ul> \n   <li><code>sip.so -&gt; /usr/local/Cellar/sip/4.19.3_1/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sip.so</code></li> \n   <li><code>PyQt4 -&gt; /usr/local/Cellar/pyqt@4/4.12_1/lib/python2.7/site-packages/PyQt4/</code></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ul> \n<p><span class=\"caps\">PS</span>:</p> \n<p>同理: OpenCV&nbsp;也一样:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>通过 brew&nbsp;一致安全稳定的自动化编译安装到系统环境中</li> \n <li>然后, 手工通过链接形式加载到对应 pyenv&nbsp;版本环境中</li> \n</ul> \n<p>所以, macOS 本质是 <span class=\"caps\">UNIX</span> 系统, 用 linux 的环境配置思路是好的, 但是,又为了易用, macOS 也进行了各种妥协,&nbsp;好在程序猿界总是能第一时间给出对应的嗯哼</p> \n<p>只是不通过 google&nbsp;简直了,不知道何时才能从弥散回来的文章中知道嗯哼…</p> \n<blockquote> \n class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#cbi\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p><a href=\"http://blog.zhgdg.org/2014-01/et-cbi1/\">CBInstall.1 欢乐完成</a>&nbsp;记要了现场活动的情况;</p> \n<p>当然,俺也是学员之一,要交作业的,所以,俺的刷机笔记如下:</p> \n<h2 id=\"_1\">目标<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#_1\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>用<span class=\"caps\">CB3</span> 替代原先的兼容 <span class=\"caps\">PC</span>&nbsp;机作家庭服务器!</p> \n<h2 id=\"_2\">环境<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#_2\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<ul> \n <li><span class=\"caps\">MBP</span> 11年下半年版,&nbsp;15吋</li> \n <li><span class=\"caps\">MAC</span> <span class=\"caps\">OS</span> X 10.9&nbsp;Mavericks</li> \n <li><span class=\"caps\">CB3</span>(CubieTruck)&nbsp;以及套件的配件</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"_3\">刷机<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#_3\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>果然如宣传的,是那么简单!</p> \n<ol> \n <li>准备工具 ~ <a href=\"http://docs.cubieboard.org/tutorials/common/livesuit_installation_guide\">LiveSuit</a> </li> \n <li>下载镜像 ~ <a href=\"http://dl.cubieboard.org/software\"><span class=\"caps\">NAND</span>镜像</a></li> \n <li>刷机</li> \n</ol> \n<p>尝试了 arch linux 的镜像,发觉进入后包管理命令,完全不熟悉,所以,只好坚持使用&nbsp;Ubuntu了.</p> \n<h3 id=\"_4\">细节<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#_4\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h3> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://docs.cubieboard.org/tutorials/common/livesuit_installation_guide\">LiveSuit</a> 真心傻瓜,在<span class=\"caps\">MAC</span>&nbsp;上完全无碍!</li> \n</ul> \n<p><img alt=\"livesuit_mac\" src=\"http://zoomq.qiniudn.com/ZHGDG/2014/140111-CBInstallfest.1/livesuit_mac.png\" /></p> \n<ul> \n <li> <p>下载时,为了大家的幸福,不要下载 .img 的文件,下载压缩的 .gz&nbsp;文档本地解开就好</p> <p>$ 7z x&nbsp;lubuntu-server-nand.img.gz</p> </li> \n <li> <p>为了防止手指意外的摸到带电元件,应该先将赠送的<span class=\"caps\">PV</span>板安装上,注意: <img alt=\"cubietruck_fel_button\" src=\"http://dyhr.com/wp-content/uploads/Cubietruck_FEL_button-300x224.jpg\" /></p> \n  <ul> \n   <li>正确的次序</li> \n   <li>以及要将板上的保护膜清除</li> \n   <li>另外,应该用 <span class=\"caps\">CB</span> 驱动激光雕刻仪,来给每个<span class=\"caps\">PV</span> 板刻上 <span class=\"caps\">CB</span>小猴纸的 logo ,建议已经严正向 Benn&nbsp;吼过了</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li> <p>刷机时, <code>FEL</code> 键-<span class=\"caps\">USB</span>线-电脑的先后顺序:</p> \n  <ol> \n   <li>电脑里先运行 LiveSuit 并加载目标<span class=\"caps\">NAND</span>&nbsp;镜像</li> \n   <li>按住<code>FEL</code> 键,不松,然后插入<span class=\"caps\">USB</span>线</li> \n   <li>再将 <span class=\"caps\">USB</span>线插入电脑</li> \n   <li>然后松开 <code>FEL</code> 键</li> \n   <li>LiveSuit 识别外部 <span class=\"caps\">CB</span>&nbsp;板,开始请求确认,准备好开始刷机了</li> \n  </ol> </li> \n <li> <p>刷机一般5分钟以内就可以完成:</p> \n  <ul> \n   <li>LiveSute 进度 100%&nbsp;提示已经完成</li> \n   <li><span class=\"caps\">CB</span> 板上的几个 <span class=\"caps\">LED</span>&nbsp;灯开始闪动</li> \n   <li>这时,可以长按板上的 <code>POWER ON</code> 键,进行热关闭</li> \n   <li>等板上的灯都更灭时,代表 <span class=\"caps\">CB</span>&nbsp;已经加载的系统完全终止运行</li> \n   <li>这时就可以拔下 <span class=\"caps\">USB</span>&nbsp;线了</li> \n   <li>再将 <span class=\"caps\">CB</span>&nbsp;的电源插入,刷好的系统就真正自举运行起来了!</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li> <p>首次启动系统时, Ubuntu 会尝试获得当前的网络<span class=\"caps\">IP</span>,&nbsp;而且过期时间定为60秒,我们就只能安静的等哈等! </p> \n  <ul> \n   <li>这绝对是应该优化的默认配置.</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ul> \n<p><img alt=\"ct_default_py.png（PNG 图像，814x201 像素）\" src=\"http://zoomq.qiniudn.com/ZHGDG/2014/140111-CBInstallfest.1/ct_default_py.png\" /></p> \n<ul> \n <li>默认安装了Python&nbsp;点赞!</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"_5\">问题<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#_5\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<ol> \n <li> <p>对于可以通过内核接口,调整板上 <span class=\"caps\">LED</span>&nbsp;灯的事儿</p> \n  <ul> \n   <li>这么有趣,为毛不给出对应的文档?</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li> <p>两次都上了 Nand 镜像文件名的当!&nbsp;比如: </p> <p>:::text http://dl.cubieboard.org/software/a20-cubietruck/lubuntu/ \\ ct-lubuntu-nand-v1.01/ct-lubuntu-server/lubuntu-server-nand.img.gz ct-lubuntu-nand-v1.00/ct-lubuntu-server-20131026/lubuntu-server-nand.img.gz ct-lubuntu-nand-v1.00/<span class=\"caps\">VGA</span>/lubuntu-server-nand.img.gz</p> </li> \n</ol> \n<p>从下载路径的确可以看出是针对什么的镜像; 但是,无论哪种版本的镜像, lubuntu 的下载下来 都是 <code>lubuntu-server-nand.img.gz</code> 解压缩 也都是 <code>lubuntu-server-nand.img</code> 根本就看不出什么是什么了!&nbsp;强烈建议,重新制定版本规范,也包含最终下载文件名;比如:</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><span class=\"n\">ct</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">lubuntu</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"mf\">13.06</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">server</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">nand</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"n\">img</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"n\">gz</span>\n<span class=\"n\">ct</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">vga</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">lubuntu</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"mf\">13.06</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">server</span><span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">nand</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"n\">img</span><span class=\"p\">.</span><span class=\"n\">gz</span>\n</pre> \n</div> \n<h3 id=\"vga\"><span class=\"caps\">VGA</span><a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#vga\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h3> \n<p>是的,兴冲冲,回家准备接上网络,开始家庭服务器的配置! 结果发现,5年前的液瞐屏幕接上没有反应!&nbsp;再扛来老婆的新液瞐屏也是只有间或的白色闪线,没有信号输出!</p> \n<p>这就要了亲命! </p> \n<ul> \n <li>命令行上加载驱动,启动wifi&nbsp;接入家庭无线网络,不是不行,只是没必要,因为以后的正当运行环境是拉网线的</li> \n <li>然而,网络和能接 <span class=\"caps\">HDMI</span>&nbsp;的液瞐电视不是一房,没办法现拉根网线去</li> \n</ul> \n<p>所以,果断 google 之! 果然,是常见问题! 居然 <span class=\"caps\">VGA</span>&nbsp;的输出是需要特殊系统镜像的!</p> \n<p>这也才发现, <span class=\"caps\">CB3</span> 的 <span class=\"caps\">VGA</span> 支持系统镜像,居然只有在 <code>lubuntu-nand-v1.00</code> 中有, <code>lubuntu-nand-v1.01</code> 中还没有完成兼容!</p> \n<p>重新刷上对口的 <span class=\"caps\">OS</span>,&nbsp;这下子终于见到熟悉的命令行界面了!!!</p> \n<p>但是:</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre>Welcome to Linaro 13.08 (GNU/Linux 3.4.61+ armv7l)\n\n * Documentation:  https://wiki.linaro.org/\nNew release '13.10' available.\nRun 'do-release-upgrade' to upgrade to it.\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>这倒底是升级呢?&nbsp;还是不升级呢?!</p> \n<h3 id=\"ip\"><span class=\"caps\">IP</span><a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#ip\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h3> \n<p>修订: <code>/etc/network/interfaces</code> 为:</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre>auto lo eth0\niface lo inet loopback\n<span class=\"c\">#iface eth0 inet dhcp</span>\niface eth0 inet static\n\naddress 192.168.0.111\ngateway 192.168.0.1\nnetmask 255.255.255.0\nnetwork 192.168.0.0\nbroadcast 192.168.0.255\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>重启网络:</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre>/etc/init.d/networking restart\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>就将原先每次重启时,可能变化的动态 <span class=\"caps\">IP</span> 变成内网的静态 <span class=\"caps\">IP</span>&nbsp;了</p> \n<h3 id=\"connection-refused\">Connection refused<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#connection-refused\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h3> \n<p>然后,配置了 <code>sudo</code> 用户,刷了初始口令,就可以离开 <span class=\"caps\">VGA</span>&nbsp;远程随时随地进行控制了!</p> \n<p>可是竟然反馈说: <code>Connection refused</code></p> \n<p>果断 Google&nbsp;发布,是常见问题!</p> \n<p><a href=\"http://askubuntu.com/questions/30080/how-to-solve-connection-refused-errors-in-ssh-connection\">openssh - How to solve ‘Connection refused’ errors in <span class=\"caps\">SSH</span> connection? - Ask&nbsp;Ubuntu</a></p> \n<p>完全无法相信自个儿的眼睛! 竟然是因为根本没有 <code>sshd</code> 进程运行的原因!</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre>sudo apt-get install openssh-server openssh-client\nsudo /etc/init.d/ssh start\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>再尝试</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><span class=\"err\">$</span> <span class=\"n\">ssh</span> <span class=\"mf\">192.168.0.111</span>\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>一切正常了!</p> \n<h3 id=\"ftab\">ftab<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#ftab\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h3> \n<p>看<span class=\"caps\">CB3</span> 的硬件参数,应该有8G 内置空间的,&nbsp;但是查询:</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><span class=\"err\">$</span> <span class=\"n\">df</span> <span class=\"o\">-</span><span class=\"n\">h</span>\n<span class=\"n\">partition</span> <span class=\"n\">table</span>\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>果然有 <code>/dev/nandc</code> 没有挂上;</p> \n<p>于是,先建立文件系统:</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre>mkfs.ext4 /dev/nandc\nmke2fs 1.42.5 (29-Jul-2012)\nFilesystem label=\nOS type: Linux\nBlock size=4096 (log=2)\nFragment size=4096 (log=2)\n...\n\nAllocating group tables: done\nWriting inode tables: done\nCreating journal (32768 blocks):\ndone\nWriting superblocks and filesystem accounting information: done\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>然后,不折腾,直接使用: <code>/etc/rc.local</code></p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><span class=\"n\">sudo</span> <span class=\"n\">mount</span> <span class=\"o\">/</span><span class=\"n\">dev</span><span class=\"o\">/</span><span class=\"n\">nandc</span> <span class=\"o\">/</span><span class=\"n\">mnt</span><span class=\"o\">/</span><span class=\"n\">nandc</span>\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>追加一行,完成!&nbsp;这样重启时,将在最后一刻重新挂接上丢失的分区</p> \n<h3 id=\"_6\">其它<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#_6\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h3> \n<p>习惯性的安装 <code>htop</code> 一看:</p> \n<p><img alt=\"ct_default_deamon.png（PNG 图像，1005x709 像素）\" src=\"http://zoomq.qiniudn.com/ZHGDG/2014/140111-CBInstallfest.1/ct_default_deamon.png\" /></p> \n<p>目测, 这一镜像的程序猿是 <code>LAMP</code> 标准屌丝web&nbsp;程序猿哪!!!</p> \n<p>按惯例, <code>server</code> 版的发行系统镜像,应该是最小运维依赖核心系统:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>有最稳定的&nbsp;内核</li> \n <li>包含最常见的系统工具</li> \n <li>包含最常见的硬件驱动</li> \n <li>默认启动 <code>sshd</code></li> \n <li>默认配置好 <code>apt-fast</code> ~ 用 axel 来加速 apt-get&nbsp;软件安装</li> \n <li>..etc. 总之是面向 <span class=\"caps\">SA</span>&nbsp;的一个方便环境</li> \n</ul> \n<p>怎么也没有想到,默认是启动跑了 <code>MySQL</code>+<code>Apache</code> 这两种一般 <span class=\"caps\">SA</span>&nbsp;一见就删除的东西</p> \n<p>有点 <code>细思恐极</code> <span class=\"caps\">CB</span> 应该及时提升自个儿 <span class=\"caps\">SA</span>&nbsp;的运营观念了,不能停留在上世纪了呢…</p> \n<h1 id=\"todo\"><span class=\"caps\">TODO</span><a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#todo\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h1> \n<p>为了完全替代俺家原先的家庭服务器,可以支持多系统的内网络使用,&nbsp;还要折腾的事儿有:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>通过 <span class=\"caps\">USB</span> 挂接 FreeBSD 格式化的 <span class=\"caps\">UFS</span>&nbsp;分区</li> \n <li>通过板载 <span class=\"caps\">SATA</span> 接口,加装 2.5吋 1T&nbsp;新硬盘</li> \n <li>安装 Samba 系统,提供空间给其它 M$&nbsp;设备使用</li> \n <li>安装 netatalk ,支持 <code>Apple Time Machine</code></li> \n <li>安装 MLDonkey 通过网页控制 <code>P2P</code> 下载</li> \n <li>安装 MiniDLNA&nbsp;发布家庭媒体服务,支持远程播放下载的电影</li> \n</ol> \n<p>…</p> \n<p>总之,要搾干 <span class=\"caps\">CB</span>&nbsp;的一切潜能!</p> \n<h1 id=\"_7\">参考:<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/cbi-zq-install.html#_7\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h1> \n<p><a href=\"http://dyhr.com/2013/11/22/how-to-install-lubuntu-server-on-cubietruck-from-mac-os-x/\">How \n</ul>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 10 Jan 2014 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":2079,"bgimg":"http://zoomq.qiniudn.com/ZHGDG/2014/140111-CBInstallfest.1/livesuit_mac.png","linkMd5":"37b63aa5d55cbe639430f64dc45bf8f2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn42@2020_3/2020/08/24/14-59-17-563_63a79cbc4f1abeac.jpg","destWidth":0,"destHeight":0,"sourceBytes":4028,"destBytes":4028,"author":"Zoom.Quiet","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://zoomq.qiniudn.com/ZHGDG/2014/140111-CBInstallfest.1/livesuit_mac.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn42@2020_3/2020/08/24/14-59-17-563_63a79cbc4f1abeac.jpg","http://dyhr.com/wp-content/uploads/Cubietruck_FEL_button-300x224.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn66@2020_5/2020/08/24/14-59-32-375_60eb1f5698b702e1.webp","http://zoomq.qiniudn.com/ZHGDG/2014/140111-CBInstallfest.1/ct_default_py.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn2@2020_4/2020/08/24/14-59-26-826_64821ccefcb1f53b.jpg","http://zoomq.qiniudn.com/ZHGDG/2014/140111-CBInstallfest.1/ct_default_deamon.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn1@2020_4/2020/08/24/14-59-28-102_522bc451865807fe.jpg"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598281148766},{"createdTime":"2020-08-24 22:59:08","updatedTime":"2020-08-24 22:59:08","title":"S02E01/周生剧本大纲","link":"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html","description":"<h2 id=\"toc\">[<span class=\"caps\">TOC</span>]<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#toc\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<h1 id=\"s02e01\"><span class=\"caps\">S02E01</span>: 周生剧本大纲<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#s02e01\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h1> \n<p>演员设定: </p> \n<ul> \n <li>周生生: 姜文&nbsp;(红高梁时期的)</li> \n <li>秀娘:&nbsp;娜塔莎.波特曼</li> \n <li>郑和:&nbsp;吴秀波</li> \n <li>郑爽:&nbsp;文章</li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"_1\">双闯西洋<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_1\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<ul> \n <li>(宣德五年三月十三日)</li> \n <li>[泉州城西郊,&nbsp;强生豆腐店,后门]</li> \n</ul> \n<p>秀娘,从后看只是个普通的大明及笄少女,只是生有奇怪的褐色头发;但是,正面一看就知道不是中原人,高鼻绿瞳;&nbsp;在温州地区,总是有行商失败的大食人后代流落善堂,想来这个面色焦急的少女也是相似的身世.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>生哥!&nbsp;生哥!”</p> \n <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>阿秀,你怎么来了?”</p> \n <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>生哥! 阿爷已为我报名织绣营了,年末就要和三宝大人出洋了!”&nbsp;…</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>送走阿秀,周生生下了决心,转身和东家辞行, 然后径直去东门,揭了西洋舰队官榜, 作为厨师入了辎重营; 又以加温来加速发豆芽的独门技术, 配合腌金桔可防/治败血症的功劳,进入郑和的视野, 成为第七次西洋舰队第42&nbsp;粮船的辎重队队副.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>(宣德五年十一月十一)</li> \n <li>[珠江口,&nbsp;虎门港]</li> \n</ul> \n<p>240多艘各型海船,浩浩荡荡,在礼炮的欢送下,缓缓驶向外海. 其中一艘粮船上,进行仪仗队列的人群中, 周生生偷偷看向甲板中间织绣营队列; 心有灵犀般,垂着头的秀娘,微微偏头,&nbsp;准确的对上了周生生的眼睛.</p> \n<p>两个大明朝普通的青年,&nbsp;为了对抗命运,开始了未知的旅程.</p> \n<h2 id=\"_2\">月背黑石<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_2\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>2020年11月11日, 月背<span class=\"caps\">USA</span>&nbsp;静海基地,</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>嘀! 嘀! 嘀!” 控制台警告声吵醒了值班员, 看了眼屏幕:”shit 又坏了.” 随即,调无人机到矿区上空, 才发现, 在矿务机器人自动作业下,&nbsp;一个倒方锥形,有10公里见方的矿坑底部,暴露出了一个纯粹几何外形的非自然物体!</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>一阵鸡飞狗跳的调查,以及考察性挖掘后, 明确这是一座长高宽,9:3:1 精确比例的四棱锥.&nbsp;仅挖出的部分,周长就已经有300米,</p> \n<p><code>黑的象没有尺度</code>…</p> \n<p>又一个早晨,阳光在无数年后,终于再照射到黑石尖顶, 瞬间一次宏大的无线电脉冲从月球射向深空, 有非常惊人的指向性, 只有在信号路径上的各种接收器,才收到:”嗡!&nbsp;嗡—嗡!”</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>喂, 喂… 喂! 这个情景好象在哪里看到过啊!”&nbsp;一名宅男样技术员,在显示屏上看到模拟的波峰后,下意识的说.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>宇宙中,一股能量波精确的指向火星发射而去.</p> \n<h3 id=\"_3\">隐岛失魂<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_3\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h3> \n<ul> \n <li>(宣德6年九月十日,当地子时)</li> \n <li>[旗舰宝船,舰长室]</li> \n</ul> \n<blockquote> \n <p>郑和:”子爽,到底那场暴风雨后发生了什么?!”</p> \n <p>郑爽:”族叔公,都是周生生引发的事端…”</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>半月前,舰队在东非外洋,遭遇暴风雨,&nbsp;郑爽统领的辎重队被冲散,只余两艘船停靠在一无名大岛上….</p> \n<p>其中一艘舯部受损,需要上岛收集合适的材料来修补. 周生生作为志愿者进入岛深处,&nbsp;独自发现了一处有无数洞窟的山崖.</p> \n<p>入夜, 周生生 偷偷从舷窗外,唤醒 秀娘 意图私奔. 却被外围的暗哨发现. 好在事先探好通路, 俩人总算领先半步逃入了 隐窟 , 但被卫队逐步逼至窟底, 是一扇被异族花纹装饰的异常庄严的门, 门内 <code>黑的象没有尺度</code> 俩人决然闯入,漾起星光样光纹再无音讯.</p> \n<p>郑爽带队赶到,尝试各种方法都无法和进入的人/物产生影响. 感觉太过诡异,又根据门楣雕刻推断是黄泉入口.&nbsp;惊恐的封了洞窟,回航.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>郑和:”此事太过凶兆,下封口令,不得记入日帐!”</p> \n <p>郑爽:”诺!”</p> \n</blockquote> \n<h2 id=\"_4\">天宫危机<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_4\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<ul> \n <li>2046年12月12日,触发黑石信号同一时刻,</li> \n <li>&lt;火星同步轨道中国<code>天宫</code>宇航站&gt;</li> \n</ul> \n<blockquote> \n <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>嘀! 嘀!&nbsp;嘀!”</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>控制台报警随着闪动的桔红警灯响起,&nbsp;严阵以待的宇航员立即按照预案行动起来:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>关闭所有隔仓</li> \n <li>关闭所有不必要系统</li> \n <li>调整姿势,将头部面向冲击方向</li> \n</ul> \n<p>420秒后,失事的俄国运载飞船残骸如约而至!&nbsp;暴雨般的大小残骸飞掠,不可避免的有几个撞击到天宫</p> \n<p>有的撞歪跳走了, 有的撞凹了外壁粉碎,&nbsp;更有的穿入舱体!</p> \n<p><code>天宫</code>中央的居住舱,7名宇航员,惊恐的望着对面的舱壁.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>警告! 警告!气密性破损!” 伴随更加尖锐的警告声, 前后多处穿透. 多数被速凝胶堵住, 但是,有一处刚好在接缝处,被高速逸出的空气撕开越来越大.&nbsp;紧急时刻,一位高大队员,直接坐了上去,用屁股堵住破孔.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>幸好穿了宇航服,立即脱下,并堆上速凝胶.</p> \n<p>残骸雨仅仅20秒就通过了,但是,40分钟后,将再次来袭!&nbsp;大家相互看着,无言以对.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>咳,有哉屋底呢弗?” </p> \n <p>(<code>有人z屋底啊弗啊</code>)</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>突然,全舰响起一句温州话.</p> \n<h2 id=\"_5\">黑石来客<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_5\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>火卫3背面,三座上百公里长的方尖石紧密的耸立在一起. 三个尖顶组成的正三角形虚空, 忽然亮起银河般的光辉, 一抹正圆形黑影从中心出现, 缓缓拉出,形成标准圆柱体,&nbsp;有42公里长,4.2公里直径.</p> \n<p>入内, 各三条陆地和天空间夹形成了内部居住空间. 通过持续稳定旋转,获得人工重力.&nbsp;中心是交通柱,如树枝,间或关联到各个陆地区.</p> \n<p>在交通柱中心控制核区:</p> \n<p>外形象石墨烯球, 数十米见方,中空的一个构件中,亮起辉光. 一闪而泯后, 落下天宫中,所有宇航员. 大家先后醒过神来,张目忘去, 两鬓见霜的 周生生&nbsp;依然穿着号坎迎上来…</p> \n<h2 id=\"_6\">生生不忘<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_6\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>一年后, 当年 郑爽 逃离的迷岛所在,海底. 中国远洋科考察队,<code>天涯</code>11号深渊着陆器, 在10240米处,重新找到了当年的洞窟.&nbsp;打开封口,机器人重新观察到了黑石门.</p> \n<p>架设好小型传送巢后, 辉光亮起, 两鬓见霜的 周生生 竟然没穿任何保护服, 只是样式古早的长衫, 沉静, 但是无法压抑激动样,&nbsp;缓缓走入黑石.</p> \n<p>在洋面上, 核心实验室广大的球形全息显示屏环绕的控制仓中, 原<code>天宫</code>宇航队长赫然在列,和几十位不同部门的专家在围观.</p> \n<p>仅几分钟后,辉光再闪, 周生生走出来,怀抱一样东西,&nbsp;回到传送巢…相似的辉光再闪…</p> \n<h2 id=\"_7\">秀娘离魂<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_7\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<ul> \n <li>(宣德6年七月四日)</li> \n</ul> \n<p>进入黑石后,类似后来圆柱形飞船控制中心的空间, 追兵还是围上了秀娘和周生生, 关键时刻秀娘护住 周生生,自己受了重伤, 智能系统才反应过来,迅速制止了暴行, 将其它官兵传送走后, 救治了 周生生,期间,和建立了沟通方式—使用手写板, 通过文字进行初步交流,&nbsp;明确了现状:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>这是一个星际中转站</li> \n <li>单向负责发送原 <code>亚特兰提斯</code> 帝国的留守人员</li> \n <li>秀娘身体受损过重难以承受传送</li> \n <li>只能先抽取魂魄寄养在魂器中静待机缘</li> \n <li>中转站资源有限,&nbsp;无法长期供应生命体</li> \n</ul> \n<p>周生生&nbsp;只能选择离开</p> \n<h2 id=\"_8\">深深不弃<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_8\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>四年后,已经出发12年的中华深空移民船,<code>息壤</code>号的通讯中心,&nbsp;忽然收到海量来自地球的数据包…</p> \n<p>经过紧张的处理,发现是一个结构体的设计图纸 和刚刚成立的地球人类<code>星际联盟</code>(<span class=\"caps\">EHSU</span>),&nbsp;对所有深空移民舰队的统一指令.</p> \n<p>紧张的制造和调试后, 专门腾空的货仓中央, 尺寸更加大的 传送巢 亮起辉光: 重新年轻的周生生和秀娘出现在 传送巢&nbsp;中!</p> \n<p>…</p> \n<h2 id=\"_9\">彩蛋<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_9\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<blockquote> \n <p>没有彩蛋的电影是没有灵魂的…</p> \n</blockquote> \n<h3 id=\"_10\">魂器<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_10\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h3> \n<p>无数年后,地球文明果然被人类自己毁灭了, 轨道上卫星都变成了残骸, 所有城市都变成了废墟, 海洋变成灰色的…&nbsp;真正的灭世!</p> \n<p>在北京西山深处,依然运转的安全仓中,&nbsp;一组魂器,闪动着桔色的微光,表示保有灵魂中…</p> \n<h3 id=\"_11\">大明<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_11\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h3> \n<p>无数光年外,类似太阳系的系统中, 黑石,不在卫星,而是在类地行星上, 体积也更加宏大, 不过是横置的, 从三个尖顶组成的正三角形虚空中, 缓慢突出的,是有大明建筑风格的大气层内飞行母舰,&nbsp;主控中心,坐在舰长位置的,赫然是当年追入黑石的一名内卫!</p> \n<h2 id=\"_12\">是也乎<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_12\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre><span class=\"err\">剧本剧本</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"err\">一剧之本</span>\n<span class=\"err\">故事架构</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"err\">情节所依</span>\n<span class=\"err\">开放封闭</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"err\">皆须逻辑</span>\n<span class=\"err\">人物情感</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"err\">才得寄所</span>\n<span class=\"err\">是也乎哉</span><span class=\"p\">,</span> <span class=\"err\">吾之浅见</span>\n</pre> \n</div> \n<blockquote> \n <p>嗯哼</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>最早见到的剧本, 是 2002 年找到的风之谷的英文版本剧本,&nbsp;才知道剧本是要将故事有序分解为:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>场景</li> \n <li>行为</li> \n <li>对话</li> \n <li>心情</li> \n</ul> \n<p>才能指导后续所有其它艺术创作的.</p> \n<p>但是,后来自己尝试写剧本, 才发现远没那么简单. 再后来,看电影/剧集, 也开始从成品自发的逆向工程剧本, 然后,见到了 star war 剧本原稿照片, 内心无垠 <span class=\"caps\">WTF</span> … 才知道,&nbsp;天才就在于,从简单结构故事中育发出无数细节.</p> \n<p>因为,编程有早已包含无数细节的开源模块和编译器来协助,&nbsp;影视剧本,可真心要从虚空中无中生有!</p> \n<p>不过,撰写冲动总是有的, 明知故事太嗯哼, 却是淤塞住了其它构思,非得写出来不可.&nbsp;上周课程末尾,一说剧本大纲,立即脑中跳出了以下关系链:</p> \n<div class=\"highlight\"> \n <pre>  郑和<span class=\"o\">-&gt;</span>非洲<span class=\"o\">-&gt;</span>亚特兰提斯\n          <span class=\"o\">-&gt;</span>黑石\n            <span class=\"o\">|</span> <span class=\"o\">-&gt;</span>月球 <span class=\"o\">&lt;-</span>USA\n            <span class=\"o\">+-&gt;</span>… <span class=\"o\">-&gt;</span>火星<span class=\"o\">&lt;-</span>中国 <span class=\"o\">&lt;-</span>危机\n                <span class=\"o\">-&gt;</span>深空\n</pre> \n</div> \n<p>接下来,发现,根本就是以往看过的一堆 SiFi 小说的混合物, 原创部分异常的少, 但是,死活丢不干净这一事件链相关的念头矣! 只好硬着头皮, 先立场景标题,再设计人物, 合理化所有情节背景… 哗的一下,就过了2500字. 再改, 也就按照电影的时间顺序重新排一下叙述线索, 吻合: <code>起承转合</code> 的心理节奏就好.</p> \n<p>问题在:场景切换这么大尺度的 SiFi&nbsp;电影,竟然没有一个核心矛盾的爆发点!</p> \n<h2 id=\"_13\">用时<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/GC4-S02E01-script.html#_13\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<ul> \n <li>积累:&nbsp;36+年</li> \n <li>构思:&nbsp;1秒</li> \n <li>结构:&nbsp;两次重构</li> \n <li>初稿: .5h&nbsp;500+字</li> \n <li>再稿: .5h&nbsp;300+字,全新结构,放弃</li> \n <li>三稿: 4h, 2200+字,&nbsp;分4次碎片时间撰写,恢复原先故事大纲</li> \n <li>四稿: 1&nbsp;h,回珠海飞机上,调整/删节大纲,增补细节点</li> \n <li>五稿: .5h review&nbsp;错别字,调整格式,发布简书</li> \n</ul>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 01 Apr 2017 11:42:00 class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/livin-scrapbook.html#_1\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>很久以前,&nbsp;俺和大家一样,收集整理网络资源的习惯组织方式是:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>目录 (htm&nbsp;抓网页)</li> \n <li>刻光盘</li> \n</ul> \n<p>然后,发觉目录/内容超过两屏后基本什么也找不到了, 当然,后来使用了 google 的桌面搜索, 当然,那时还是 M$&nbsp;时代,</p> \n<p>不过,在这个折腾的过程中,也明确了:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>资料的收集要配合自个儿的知识框架</li> \n <li>搜索也必须知道搜索什么,而中文的岐义/复义/多义&nbsp;太多,基本不可用作搜索关键词</li> \n <li>pdf/word/ppt&nbsp;之类的专用格式文档基本是废的,无法快速使用</li> \n</ul> \n<p>所以,后来上了 FireFox 后,用上了 ScrapBook 这一杀手级扩展,&nbsp;资料的收集过程变成:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>浏览过程中,自然的挖掘,随手抓取到临时分类中</li> \n <li>快速精读一遍,用内置高亮工具,标注重点</li> \n <li>合理移动到对应的分类中</li> \n <li>使用时,直接进入对应分类,或是用标题关键词搜索出来</li> \n</ol> \n<p>ScrapBook&nbsp;是结合了本地目录管理+内置全文搜索的浏览器扩展工具.</p> \n<p>一切安定了起来</p> \n<h2 id=\"_2\">发展<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/livin-scrapbook.html#_2\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>慢慢的,快速收集整理了上万个网页,才发现,好的网页内容:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>一般不长久,原始网站总是很快死亡</li> \n <li>而相同的内容在多次转抄过程中总是有丢失</li> \n <li>Google&nbsp;的搜索镜像也不一定靠谱</li> \n <li>大家通过书签记录的网页,基本上90天后就很难点击开了</li> \n</ul> \n<p>所以,就有了将个人收集分享出来的想法:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>ScrapBook&nbsp;有导出目录树的功能</li> \n <li>所以,一开始就是简单的进行导出</li> \n <li>然后,用 rsync&nbsp;同步到自个儿的官网空间</li> \n</ul> \n<p>但是,慢慢的,网络数量突破3万时,根索引的目录树就超过了10M!</p> \n<ul> \n <li>大家就反应首页很难打开了</li> \n <li>这才知道真的有人在俺的分享网站中找东西!</li> \n</ul> \n<p>于是有了: <a href=\"https://github.com/ZoomQuiet/scrapbooktools/blob/master/expidxlevels.py\">scrapbooktools/expidxlevels.py at master ·&nbsp;ZoomQuiet/scrapbooktools</a></p> \n<p>单纯的原样分享就变成了:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://floss.zoomquiet.io/tree/\">{ZqFLOSS} index tree exp. As <span class=\"caps\">HTML</span> -&nbsp;ScrapBook</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"http://skm.zoomquiet.io/tree/\">{ZqSKM} index tree exp. As <span class=\"caps\">HTML</span> -&nbsp;ScrapBook</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h2 id=\"_3\">问题<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/livin-scrapbook.html#_3\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>但是,突然有一天,无法在常用的 ScrapBook 界面中对标题进行搜索了&nbsp;能将整个浏览器都卡死…</p> \n<p>再查, <code>ZqFLOSS</code> 目录已经突破5万页面,索引 xml 也超过了 25&nbsp;M!</p> \n<p>不得以再次分库,并分享:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"http://devrel.zoomquiet.io/tree/\">{ZqDevRel} index tree exp. As <span class=\"caps\">HTML</span> -&nbsp;ScrapBook</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>可是,奇怪的是分离了本地 ScrapBook 数据仓库后,问题依旧, 而且, <code>ZqFLOSS</code> 分离前有 <code>7.7G</code>; 可是拆分为两个仓库后,体积相互加,竟然几近 double&nbsp;!</p> \n<p>于是怀疑多次手工批量删除时,造成了孤悬文件,然后就有了:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://github.com/ZoomQuiet/scrapbooktools/blob/master/chkscrap.py\">scrapbooktools/chkscrap.py at master ·&nbsp;ZoomQuiet/scrapbooktools</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://github.com/ZoomQuiet/scrapbooktools/blob/master/scrap_re_rdf.py\">scrapbooktools/scrap_re_rdf.py at master ·&nbsp;ZoomQuiet/scrapbooktools</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p>分别对数据目录,以及索引 xml&nbsp;进行清查</p> \n<p>但是,只有几个丢失…</p> \n<h2 id=\"_4\">分析<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/livin-scrapbook.html#_4\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>目测是 FireFox 升级,强行切换了<span class=\"caps\">JS</span> 解析内核后,带来的少数不兼容, 导致了对一定体积的 <span class=\"caps\">XML</span>&nbsp;进行内存调度时,出了问题…</p> \n<p>暂时无法解决.</p> \n<p>已经向作者吼过,看<span class=\"caps\">RP</span>&nbsp;了…</p> \n<h1 id=\"changelog\">Changelog<a class=\"headerlink\" 立其诚<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170411-S11E01.html#s11e01\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h1> \n<p>这次要求看一部样板戏, 交出任意形式/体裁的感想来. 对平剧, 实在没积累, 只得用最平常的观后感来记述, 实在不够走心,&nbsp;主要原因不解释.</p> \n<p>为什么选择 <code>海港</code> 样板戏中最不出名的一部戏? 就是因为不出名, 好奇想一探究竟; 并且, 是唯一内容不是解放前的革命故事,&nbsp;而是贴近当时社会现实生产生活的时代剧.</p> \n<h2 id=\"_1\">概要<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170411-S11E01.html#_1\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>故事很简洁,&nbsp;上海港里左中右三派人物的交锋:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>开始, 阶段敌人单独一人, 就以丰富的破坏经验, 用最小行动,&nbsp;搞出很大规模的混乱</li> \n <li>而中间派后进分子, 思想不坚定, 被蒙骗,&nbsp;无形中拖延了事故解决</li> \n <li>最终, 正派有决心有群众有能力,&nbsp;稳步从容的解决了问题</li> \n</ul> \n<p>剧情结构也非常传统:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>问题被制造 -&gt; 被发现 -&gt;受阻 -&gt; 后进被感动转化 -&gt; 反动派被戳穿 -&gt; 一切走上正途</p> \n</blockquote> \n<h2 id=\"_2\">感动<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170411-S11E01.html#_2\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>看的是 1972 北京电影制片厂彩色电影版, 由上海京剧团出演,&nbsp;很有故事的组合.</p> \n<p>标准的毛泽东语录开画, 紧接着演职员表,才入正戏. 这细节, 配合 交响版国际歌, 就非常说明,&nbsp;当年劳动人民是统治阶级呢.</p> \n<p>因为在本地播放, 凡过于文革腔, 难以消受的,都能快速跳过, 所以,&nbsp;通观下来心态相对平稳.</p> \n<p>非常有感觉的:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>几场表现劳动现场的戏, 舞美设计实在立功了, 自发应用各种现代影视技巧: \n  <ul> \n   <li>吊车上下</li> \n   <li>拖车左右</li> \n   <li>布景前后</li> \n   <li>灯光内外</li> \n   <li>…&nbsp;在有限的舞台空间,用最少的道具,有效营造出丰富的真实感</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>第四面墙, 根本就不存在: \n  <ul> \n   <li>继承京剧现代化创新出来的平剧</li> \n   <li>虽然进行了各种创新</li> \n   <li>但并没有抛弃原有的京剧舞台语言</li> \n   <li>特别是电影/电视中,&nbsp;很少打破的第四面墙</li> \n   <li>而在这里,人物随时可以抽离剧情,&nbsp;当众进行内心独白</li> \n   <li>要是话剧,&nbsp;看起来很不自然</li> \n   <li>但戏剧唱段来表现, 却非常自然,&nbsp;毫不突兀</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>我不发火 我不发火 我不发火” \n  <ul> \n   <li>后来各种影视中出现的,以递进的态度将相同的话反复念出</li> \n   <li>这种技巧,&nbsp;原来发源在此</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>最后反动派潜逃未果, 在海上被抓捕 \n  <ul> \n   <li>惊险过程,&nbsp;却通过转述得知</li> \n   <li>反动人物并没有登场,&nbsp;进行意料中的批斗</li> \n   <li>这种调度实在高明</li> \n   <li>用最小成本完成剧情/情绪的表现</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ul> \n<p>总之, 远没有想象中的无法直视, 作为一部正剧, 实在诚意满满, 比如那个 “12公民”, 算 57年 十二怒汉 的复拍, 但是, 电影主旨和精神内核整个拧了, 远没有&nbsp;海港这般真诚透亮.</p> \n<h2 id=\"_3\">(￣▽￣)<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170411-S11E01.html#_3\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<ul> \n <li>170410 再稿,&nbsp;900字</li> \n <li>170410&nbsp;初稿</li> \n class=\"err\">我们早已联合起来了</span>\n</pre> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 27 Mar 2017 12:42:00 +0000","feedId":2079,"bgimg":"http://upload-images.jianshu.io/upload_images/27562-6d2064a29b2f5d3d.png?imageMogr2/auto-orient/strip%7CimageView2/2/w/1240","linkMd5":"02e2594954a671843e666d9518d7eef7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn58@2020_6/2020/08/24/14-59-19-843_cfa5c35057f1c7ea.webp","destWidth":220,"destHeight":215,"sourceBytes":14386,"destBytes":13090,"author":"ZoomQuiet","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://upload-images.jianshu.io/upload_images/27562-6d2064a29b2f5d3d.png?imageMogr2/auto-orient/strip%7CimageView2/2/w/1240":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn58@2020_6/2020/08/24/14-59-19-843_cfa5c35057f1c7ea.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598281148757},{"createdTime":"2020-08-24 的第<strong>010</strong>篇原创</p> \n<h1 id=\"_1\">呢喃/ 别了和队平<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/ann-murmur-farewell-peace-corps.html#_1\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h1> \n<blockquote> \n <p>普通程序老猿一则感叹…</p> \n</blockquote> \n<hr> \n <h2 id=\"_2\">背景<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/ann-murmur-farewell-peace-corps.html#_2\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n <p><a href=\"https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/-Nq2bisaZy_T5fBDD-yMsw\">呢喃/&nbsp;为什么想日历卡片连载?</a></p> \n <p>分析过原因…本质上只是开始逼自己每天至少 140&nbsp;字的文字输出.</p> \n <hr> \n  <h2 id=\"_3\">现象<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/ann-murmur-farewell-peace-corps.html#_3\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n  <blockquote> \n   <p>昨天,&nbsp;被触发了一个关键词</p> \n  </blockquote> \n  <p>不知道是图片中的文字,&nbsp;还是纯文本中的文字;</p> \n  <p>总之自动删除了;</p> \n  <p>然后, 看到 余晟&nbsp;分享的消息:</p> \n  <p>如果你看过”江城”,”寻路中国”,”再见,老北京”,”奇石”,”东北游记”,”长乐路”中的任何一本,而且喜欢这类书,你大概应该知道他们的作者都属于同一组织:和队平(the Peace Corps). 和队平成立的背景是一本1958年出版的书”丑陋的美国人(the Ugly Americans)”,作者指出,相比苏联,美国在发展中国家”接地气”的工作做得不够.&nbsp;所以和平队有三个目的:在”感兴趣的国家”提供帮助,帮助世界了解美国,帮助美国了解世界. </p> \n  <p>1996年,开始接收”和队平”,将他们派往涪陵,自贡等地区支援教育. 之前提到那些书的作者,比如何伟,梅英东,史明智,都是和队平员,他们在支教同时,也完成了中文的学习,之后更写出了不少优秀的作品. 因为各种原因,今年是”和队平”在中国的最后一年,许多人着实为之可惜.&nbsp;如果你希望了解背后的原因,或者单纯对此事感兴趣,都可以阅读何伟在”纽约客”杂志上的文章. </p> \n  <p>https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/03/16/the-peace-corps-breaks-ties-with-china</p> \n  <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>纽约客”是一份很有格调的杂志,此文词汇量不大,凝练而克制,值得一读</p> \n  <hr> \n   <h2 id=\"_4\">快译<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/ann-murmur-farewell-peace-corps.html#_4\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n   <p>…该队于1993年首次来到该国…总计派出一千三百多名志愿者到该国,&nbsp;该机构现已活跃在六十个国家,一直被视为远离政治争端单纯的志愿者组织.</p> \n   <p>1月17日正式被通知离开该国; 无论来国和该国,&nbsp;都发文庆祝.</p> \n   <p>…该队自 1961 年由 Kennedy&nbsp;总统创立…</p> \n   <p>…小平同志对该队表示过欢迎…向学生展示过从来国收到的选票…</p> \n   <p>…如今,包括亚当在内的27位前该国志愿者在国务院工作…</p> \n   <p>…一直被担心教学是情报工作的掩护…</p> \n   <p>..该队表达了美国的信心:如果您将有积极性的年轻人送到偏远地区,让他们独自一人,好事就会发生…</p> \n   <p>985工程…反映了来国人难以掌握的战略:教育和限制可以同时进行的想法..</p> \n   <p>..在随后的时期中,该国的总体增长非常强劲,以至于和队平的人数可以用微观历史来代表. </p> \n   <ul> \n    <li>China&nbsp;8(每支队伍都有正式编号)抵达的那一年,该国加入了世界贸易组织. </li> \n    <li>China 12&nbsp;到达日,三峡大坝已经建成. </li> \n    <li>China 14&nbsp;那年是北京奥运会. </li> \n    <li>…从 China 1 到 China 16 ,<span class=\"caps\">G.D.P.</span>增加了十倍以上.</li> \n   </ul> \n   <p>.. 2014年,开始允许申请人指定他们想在哪个国家或地区工作,该国因此成为了梦眛以求的任务. ..Mei Haloski..她说:”我一直被指示,技能最强的人应该去该国.&nbsp;“</p> \n   <p>…该国的战略从未改变:教育和限制并行进行,就像同一条高速公路的相反车道一样.&nbsp;…当今的公民通常更加宽容和了解,但是长防火墙城也比以往任何时候都更加复杂..</p> \n   <p>…旧的信心也消失了.&nbsp;这似乎是来国更大趋势的一部分:</p> \n   <blockquote> \n    <p>每个外国人的接触都是一种威胁,每次交换都是零和</p> \n   </blockquote> \n   <p>…二十二岁的 Gabriel Exposito 进行了电话交谈,他是最后一批收到该国和平军团邀请的人之一.<br> 他在哈瓦那长大,他的学校记忆之一就是一群来国人的来访. 校方指示孩子们避开外国人,外国人捐赠的善款被共<span class=\"caps\">CD</span>官员拒之门外..</br></p> \n   <p>…他对关闭计划的推文感到震惊,…向有关工作人员抱怨:”我同意你的观点,共<span class=\"caps\">CD</span>是一个敌对的实体.&nbsp;但是,我们正在破坏他们在树立的来国人形象啊…”</p> \n   <p>…他要求将其调任至前共产主义国家…最后选择了摩尔多瓦…</p> \n   <hr> \n    <h2 id=\"_5\">嗯哼<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/ann-murmur-farewell-peace-corps.html#_5\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n    <blockquote> \n     <p>这杂志其实也在外面, 所以, 尝试全文复制过来, 摘要翻译在上,&nbsp;另外有个小结尾测试收费功能.</p> \n     <blockquote> \n      <p>原文还配有语音和各种漫画,推荐去查阅.</p> \n     </blockquote> \n    </blockquote> \n    <p><a href=\"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/03/16/the-peace-corps-breaks-ties-with-china\">The Peace Corps Breaks Ties with China / The New&nbsp;Yorker</a></p> \n    <p>The Peace Corps Breaks Ties with&nbsp;China</p> \n    <p>The agency has always been viewed as removed from political spats. But the timing of the U.S.’s decision seems&nbsp;suspicious.</p> \n    <blockquote> \n     <p>By Peter&nbsp;Hessler</p> \n    </blockquote> \n    <p>March 9,&nbsp;2020</p> \n    <p>照片</p> \n    <p>Group of people in front of a portrait of&nbsp;Mao. </p> \n    <blockquote> \n     <p>The author, lower left, with other China 3 volunteers in front of the Forbidden City, in Beijing, in 1996.Photograph courtesy the&nbsp;author</p> \n    </blockquote> \n    <p>On the morning of January 17th, shortly before I was scheduled to meet with a hundred and forty Peace Corps volunteers in Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, there was an unexpected announcement that the China program was ending. The Peace Corps had first come to the country in 1993, and as a volunteer from the early years I had been asked to speak at an in-service training that the organization was holding in a hotel near where I live. But by the time I arrived nobody was in the mood for nostalgia. The American volunteers, most of whom were in their twenties, looked stunned; some were red-eyed from crying. At the back of the room, more than a dozen Chinese staff members stood with stoic expressions. They had given up some benefits of the Chinese system in order to work for the American agency. From the ceiling, somebody had hung a red propaganda-style banner, which proved that Americans could make their slogans every bit as tone-deaf as the ones in the People’s Republic. The banner said “Welcome to <span class=\"caps\">IST</span> 2020: Be the Tree You Wish to See in the&nbsp;World.”</p> \n    <p>An American staff member greeted me with a pained look. She said something to the effect that the tree she wished to have seen was a tactful announcement, but Senators Marco Rubio and Rick Scott, of Florida, had declared the closure of the China program on Twitter. “Rubio and Rick Scott wanted to take credit for it,” she said&nbsp;angrily.</p> \n    <p>The Peace Corps has sent more than thirteen hundred volunteers to China, and the agency, which is now active in sixty countries, has always been viewed as removed from political spats. The <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> had never ended a Peace Corps program because of a diplomatic conflict, but the timing of the decision about China seemed suspicious. The coronavirus had yet to come to widespread attention, and the Senators, who had previously expressed doubts about a Chinese trade deal, tweeted the day after President Trump signed a Phase 1 economic agreement with&nbsp;China.</p> \n    <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>For too long, Beijing has fooled organizations such as the World Bank and the World Trade Organization,” Rubio wrote. Scott chimed in: “I’m glad the Peace Corps has finally come to its senses and sees Communist China for what it is: the second largest economy in the world and an adversary of the United&nbsp;States.”</p> \n    <p>Chinese hard-liners also celebrated. In Guanchazhe, a conservative publication, a columnist named Pan Gongyu published a commentary, “Farewell, Peace Corps in China, We Won’t See You Off.” The title echoed “Farewell, Leighton Stuart!,” a famous essay that Mao Zedong wrote in August, 1949. That month, the <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> State Department had issued a white paper that, in more than a thousand tortured pages, tried to explain how America had “lost” China to Mao’s revolutionaries: “This is a frank record of an extremely complicated and most unhappy period in the life of a great country to which the United States has long been attached by ties of closest&nbsp;friendship.”</p> \n    <p>In his essay, Mao derided American democracy as “another name for the dictatorship of the bourgeoisie,” and he celebrated the departure of John Leighton Stuart, the last <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> Ambassador to China under the Kuomintang government. For years, the isolationist essay was part of the school curriculum, and many Chinese people recognize the ending: “Leighton Stuart has departed and the White Paper has arrived, very good, very good. Both events are worth&nbsp;celebrating.”</p> \n    <p>In Guanchazhe, Pan described the Peace Corps’s “ideological and cultural export” as another chapter in American failure: “After twenty-seven years in China, the <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> diplomatic offices intended to ‘raise wolves,’ but ended up with a litter of huskies.” He concluded, “The Peace Corps has departed and the U.S.-China Trade Agreement is here, very good, very good. Both events are worth&nbsp;celebrating.”</p> \n    <p>In the fall of 1996, the Peace Corps sent me to teach English to college students in Fuling, a remote city on the Yangtze River. I was twenty-seven years old, and I was joined by another volunteer, Adam Meier, who was twenty-two. Not long after we arrived, a student named Richard submitted an essay to my writing class titled “Why Americans Are So Casual.” Richard was skinny, shy, and bespectacled. He had grown up in Fuling, and most of his classmates came from the Sichuanese countryside. At the time, China’s population was more than seventy per cent rural, and only eight per cent of students went to college. Adam and I were the first Americans to live in Fuling since the Revolution. In his essay, Richard wrote, in&nbsp;English:</p> \n    <p>Our foreign language teachers—Peter and Adam—came to teach us this term. It provides a good opportunity of understanding the American way of life. In my opinion, they are more casual than Chinese people. Why do I think so? I’ll give you some facts to explain&nbsp;this.</p> \n    <p>We were part of a Peace Corps cohort known as China 3. The agency’s groups have always been numbered, perhaps because it implies a sense of mission. The Peace Corps was founded by President John F. Kennedy, in 1961—the year of Saturn 1 and Sputnik 9. In the same way that the Apollo rockets went up in sequence, each Peace Corps cohort was intended to travel to a distant land, build on the work of its predecessors, then return home. And, just like the rockets, the Peace Corps was a Cold War endeavor. It was inspired by “The Ugly American,” a 1958 novel that warned readers that the Soviets were doing a better job of grassroots work in the developing world. The Peace Corps had three goals: to provide useful assistance to “interested countries,” to improve understanding of the United States, and to help Americans understand the rest of the&nbsp;world.</p> \n    <p>By the time I joined, relatively few volunteers were aware of these Cold War roots. Time had moved on, or maybe it had stopped—this was the era of “The End of History and the Last Man,” the 1992 book by Francis Fukuyama, who declared the triumph of Western liberal democracy. In 1996, the Peace Corps was sending volunteers to Russia, Poland, Bulgaria, and other former Soviet-bloc states that had supposedly transitioned to democracy. China was the only Communist country that accepted&nbsp;volunteers.</p> \n    <p>Deng Xiaoping had welcomed the Peace Corps as part of his Reform and Opening strategy, but some Chinese officials weren’t convinced that Americans should be working in remote places like Fuling. They referred to the program by a euphemism—Meizhong Youhao Zhiyuanzhe, or “U.S.-China Friendship Volunteers”—because the Chinese translation of “Peace Corps” had been tainted by years of Maoist propaganda. The first three cohorts were small, which made it easier for the government to track us. The curiosity of locals was even more intense. Richard’s essay&nbsp;continued:</p> \n    <p>A child wakes her parents up to look at the unused space under her bed. “Can you come look under my bed? It seems like a complete waste of storage space.” Cartoon by <span class=\"caps\">P. C.</span> Vey For example, when Mr. Hessler is having class, he can scratch himself casually without paying attention to what others may say. He dresses up casually, usually with his belt dropping and dangling. But, to tell you the truth, it isn’t considered a good manner in China, especially in old people’s&nbsp;eyes.</p> \n    <p>China 3 consisted of fourteen volunteers, and, before joining, none of us had taken a single class in Chinese language, history, politics, or culture. In those days, Peace Corps applicants didn’t choose their destinations. All the China 3 volunteers were white, and had almost no experience in the developing world; one, from Mississippi, had never been on an airplane before. The majority came from the Midwest or the South—Adam was from Wisconsin, and I was a Missourian. For many of us, the Peace Corps represented an inexpensive way to go&nbsp;abroad.</p> \n    <p>Our students were majoring in English, another project of Reform and Opening. China was expanding compulsory English education, which created new demand for instructors; after graduation, our students would be assigned to teach in middle and high schools. But their concept of the outside world remained abstract. They had no Internet access, and the Communist Party published all their texts, including a cultural-studies book called “Survey of Britain and America.” A chapter about American history began, naturally enough, with China: “The Indians living in America originated from Asia some 25,000 years ago.” After listing some key details about the European discovery of the New World—”it also opened up fresh ground for the rising bourgeoisie”—the text proceeded to the founding of the United States. (“The Constitution of 1787 established the dictatorship of the American bourgeoisie.”) A section about contemporary society claimed that nowadays most New Englanders work in factories. (“They are good at making watches and clocks.”) There was some useful information about American slang. (“For example, ‘draw one’ or ‘shoot one’ means ‘pour a cup of coffee.’ “) Chapter 4 covered “Social&nbsp;Problems”:</p> \n    <p>Homosexuality is a rather strange social phenomenon that most people can hardly understand. It widely spreads. One reason for this may be the despair in marriage or love&nbsp;affairs.</p> \n    <p>The chapter concluded by explaining the primary cause of homosexuality and other social&nbsp;problems:</p> \n    <p>The most important reason is the capitalist system of America. In this capitalist society, although science and technology is highly advanced, some people are suffering from spiritual hollowness. Thus they start to look for things curious and&nbsp;exciting.</p> \n    <p>In part to keep the students as far as possible from “Survey of Britain and America,” Adam and I used whatever we could find as teaching materials. We brought photographs of family to class, and we made copies of articles from American magazines. When we received our absentee ballots for the 1996 Presidential election, Adam and I each gave a lecture on the <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> political system to a section of senior students. At the end, we took out the ballots, allowed the students to inspect them, and&nbsp;voted.</p> \n    <p>The students became very quiet when I handed them my ballot. We were in a small, unheated room, packed with more than forty simple wooden desks. One by one, the students examined the piece of paper. By the time I retrieved the ballot and voted for Bill Clinton, the room was so silent, and they were watching with such intensity, that my heart was racing. Not long afterward, a Peace Corps staffer in Chengdu reported that college officials had called and weren’t happy about what Adam and I had done. But the college left it at that—such communication was often&nbsp;indirect.</p> \n    <p>The people who were farthest away seemed the most likely to perceive a threat. Students were thrilled, whereas our Chinese colleagues were curious but guarded. College administrators were warier, but even they were proud to have foreigners on campus. Opponents of the program tended to be at the Chinese provincial or national&nbsp;level.</p> \n    <p>The American reaction was the opposite. Recently, I talked with William Speidel, a Sinologist who served as the first Peace Corps China director, and he remembered the attitude of State Department officials. “They were overjoyed,” he said. “The idea that Peace Corps had a foothold in quote-unquote Communist China was really&nbsp;something.”</p> \n    <p>Speidel commissioned a linguist to design a course in Mandarin, and, in remote places, a hardworking volunteer could gain fluency in only two years, the length of a Peace Corps assignment. Many volunteers had studied pedagogy as undergrads, and often they returned to teach in <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> classrooms. But there were others whose life paths were radically transformed. They became diplomats, civil servants, businesspeople, or scholars specializing in China. Today, twenty-seven former China volunteers, including Adam, work in the State Department, and there are others at organizations like <span class=\"caps\">U.S.A.I.D.</span></p> \n    <p>Journalists and writers were also common. Michael Meyer, a China 2 volunteer from Minnesota, went on to write three books about the country. In my cohort, three of us became China correspondents and authors. All told, former volunteers have published at least eleven nonfiction books about&nbsp;China.</p> \n    <p>I sometimes wondered how the situation looked to Communist intelligence analysts. In 1999, I moved to Beijing while preparing to publish my first book, about my experience in Fuling, and there was a period when I sensed that I was being watched with particular attention. There were strange encounters in my neighborhood, and a couple of former students back in the Fuling region reported being intimidated by security agents who showed up because of their connection with me. In Beijing, at a couple of government-sponsored events, Foreign Ministry officials sought me out with pointed questions: Why did you study English literature if you planned to go to China? Why did you teach in such an undeveloped&nbsp;place?</p> \n    <p>They clearly worried that teaching had been a cover for intelligence work, and they seemed baffled by the Peace Corps. The organization didn’t attract many people from élite backgrounds, and it paid volunteers about a hundred and twenty dollars a month. Speidel’s Chinese staff had been assigned to him by the government, so there was no question that some lines of information ran straight to security, along with the likely phone taps. But nobody from Peace Corps headquarters ever told me what I should or should not teach, and staff visited Fuling only twice in two years. At its best, the Peace Corps was an expression of American confidence: if you sent motivated young people to remote places and left them alone, good things were likely to&nbsp;happen.</p> \n    <p>Recently, I reminisced about the era with somebody from Fuling who is well connected in the Communist Party. He confided that the Fuling volunteers were supposed to be sent to Wanxian, another Yangtze city, whose name was eventually changed to Wanzhou. But officials were concerned that the city was too close to the construction site of the Three Gorges Dam, where Americans might learn sensitive information. So they pushed us a hundred and thirty miles upstream. Of course, I ended up writing about the dam anyway. And, after the Peace Corps finally got into Wanzhou, the organization posted a China 7 volunteer named Jake Hooker there. Despite having no Chinese background, Hooker learned the language to a remarkable level, and he proved that it didn’t matter who got sent downriver. In 2008, as a reporter for the Times, Hooker won a Pulitzer Prize for exposing how rural Chinese factories were exporting toxic ingredients for use in pharmaceutical&nbsp;products.</p> \n    <p>In 1998, during my last year as a volunteer, I didn’t notice two national developments that later proved to be significant. One was the system of Internet restrictions that became known in English as the Great Firewall. The other was a speech delivered by President Jiang Zemin, at Peking University, on May 4, 1998. Jiang’s words were hardly dynamic (“the future of the motherland is infinitely glorious”), but, more than twenty years later, if you say “Project 985,” many educated Chinese people recognize the reference to the year and the month of Jiang’s speech. The President called for the development of world-class universities, and this endeavor joined Project 211—the Chinese fetish for mission-oriented numerology exceeds even that of the Peace Corps. These programs involved university expansion and improvement, and they reflected a strategy that was hard for Americans to grasp: the idea that education and restriction could proceed in&nbsp;tandem.</p> \n    <p>During the period that followed, the country’s over-all growth was so intense that Peace Corps cohorts could be represented by micro-histories. The year that China 8 arrived, the country joined the World Trade Organization. By China 12, the Three Gorges Dam had been completed. China 14 was the Beijing Olympics. Between China 1 and China 16, the <span class=\"caps\">G.D.P.</span> increased more than tenfold. When I taught in Fuling, the college had about two thousand students; by China 10, there were twenty thousand, on a brand-new&nbsp;campus.</p> \n    <p>In the classroom, even smaller histories showed how the system worked at the lowest level. One of my students, a poor boy who grew up on a farm, where his family planted potatoes, corn, and tobacco, took the English name Mo. Mo’s father had a third-grade education and his mother never attended school, but a village schoolteacher inspired Mo, who became the only boy from his class to test into college. In Fuling, he joined the Communist Party, and every summer he returned home to haul sixty-pound sacks of tobacco to market. When some of Mo’s classmates started giving themselves English surnames, he asked Adam and me for advice, which was how he became Mo Money. (Another China 3 micro-history was the series of prominent deaths that occurred in the span of six months and that, at least in my mind, are forever connected: Tupac Shakur, Deng Xiaoping, and Biggie&nbsp;Smalls.)</p> \n    <p>After graduation, Mo Money accepted a teaching job in his rural home town. Among the students was his younger brother. It was the community version of education by the bootstraps: somebody escapes the village to attend college, then returns and pulls up the others. For three years, Mo taught his brother and more than forty classmates, and his brother tested into the Fuling college, too. He entered as China 8 arrived. Of the four children in Mo Money’s family, three graduated from college, and all are now middle&nbsp;class.</p> \n    <p>When this happens at scale across a population of more than a billion, the effects are staggering. Mo currently teaches in a school in Chongqing, and recently I asked him what percentage of his graduating students from last year made it to university. “Every one of them,” he said. In terms of national statistics, the college-entrance figure—seven per cent for Mo’s year—is now forty-eight per&nbsp;cent.</p> \n    <p>The Peace Corps China groups started to expand with China 4, which was also the first cohort to include an African-American volunteer. There were significantly more women than men that year, and that became the general pattern. In 2014, the Peace Corps started allowing applicants to specify which country or region they wanted to work in, and China became a coveted assignment. Yung-Mei Haloski, a China 4 volunteer who later worked in recruitment and placement for the Peace Corps, told me that China was seen as a top priority. “I was always directed that the people who had the most skills should go to China,” she&nbsp;said.</p> \n    <p>By China 17, the Peace Corps was sending between seventy and eighty volunteers per year, and the program had expanded into undeveloped parts of Gansu and Guizhou provinces. But some volunteers went to Sichuanese cities that had become much more connected and sophisticated. Chengdu acquired the nickname Gaydu, because of a relative tolerance for gay culture that would have been unimaginable during the days of “Survey of Britain and America.” (“It widely spreads.”) With China 21, the Peace Corps sent a same-sex married couple for the first&nbsp;time.</p> \n    <p>A woman sits in an armchair and reads a book. Cartoon by Will McPhail In August, 2018, Jody Olsen, the Peace Corps director appointed by President Trump, came to China to celebrate the program’s twenty-fifth anniversary. The Peace Corps hoped to move into even more remote places, and Olsen and Stephen Claborne, the head of the China program, met with officials in Beijing. The Chinese politely rejected the request. “The message was that they were happy with it the way it was,” Claborne told me&nbsp;recently.</p> \n    <p>The Chinese strategy never changed: education and restriction continued in parallel, like opposite lanes of the same highway. Today’s citizens are often more tolerant and aware, but the Great Firewall is also more sophisticated than ever. Many topics of civic interest, ranging from the Hong Kong protests to concentration camps that sequester Muslim Uighurs in Xinjiang, are highly censored. Even as the government became more comfortable with the Peace Corps, it restricted other organizations, and a 2017 law made it increasingly difficult for foreign <span class=\"caps\">N.G.O.</span>s to operate. If you connect all the micro-histories—each individual improvement in material and educational circumstance—they still don’t add up to political change. Mo Money remains a member of the Communist&nbsp;Party.</p> \n    <p>In 2018, during a visit to Fuling, I happened to run into my first-year student Richard. Like Mo, Richard has prospered as a high-school teacher. During our conversation, he quickly brought up the lecture about absentee ballots. “That made a deep impression,” he said. “I’ve always thought about&nbsp;that.”</p> \n    <p>Recently, a couple of other former students also mentioned the incident in positive terms, which surprised me. I had thought of it as a clumsy attempt by two young teachers to deal with a frustrating political environment. Even now, I can’t tell exactly what lessons the students took away. I occasionally send survey questions to the people I taught, and in 2017 I asked if China should become a multiparty democracy. Out of thirty respondents, twenty-two said no. “China is going well this way,” one former student wrote. Others were more cynical. “We already have one corrupt party, it will be much worse if we have more,” one man wrote. Another student remarked, “We have seen America with multi-party, but you have elected the worst president in human’s&nbsp;history.”</p> \n    <p>Rick Scott began demanding an end to Peace Corps China in the summer of 2019. “What the Peace Corps shouldn’t be doing is propping up our adversaries with <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> tax dollars,” the Senator said, in a statement. Such criticism had also been made in 2011, by Mike Coffman, a Republican congressman from Colorado. Scott introduced a bill that would cancel programs “in hostile countries, like China,” and place the Peace Corps under the oversight of the State&nbsp;Department.</p> \n    <p><span class=\"caps\">VIDEO</span> <span class=\"caps\">FROM</span> <span class=\"caps\">THE</span> <span class=\"caps\">NEW</span> <span class=\"caps\">YORKER</span> A Couple’s Last Words to Each&nbsp;Other</p> \n    <p>The agency has always functioned independently within the executive branch, in part to prevent programs from being manipulated as direct tools of foreign policy. No other senators signed on to Scott’s bill, but he continued to attack the Peace Corps and China. His criticism of both seemed to be recent. Before entering politics, Scott reportedly amassed a fortune of more than two hundred million dollars as an entrepreneur in the health-care industry. In two terms as governor of Florida, from 2011 to 2019, Scott welcomed Chinese investors to the state, and he chaired Enterprise Florida, a pro-business consortium that has offices in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Beijing. A blind trust held by the Governor included stocks with ties to Chinese&nbsp;companies.</p> \n    <p>Once Scott entered the Senate, though, he became a vocal opponent of China. In response to the Senator’s pressure, Claborne, the head of the China program, received an unusual request from Peace Corps headquarters. Scott wanted to analyze Peace Corps China in business terms, examining the return on investment. “He was looking for things like how many volunteers came back and started businesses and created wealth because of their work in China,” Claborne told&nbsp;me.</p> \n    <p>Claborne worried that somebody with little understanding of the Peace Corps was being allowed to redefine how it should be valued. He also believed that Scott’s point that China is now a developed nation was irrelevant. Nothing in the Peace Corps mission statement specifies that partner countries must be poor, and the agency often looks closely at the Human Development Index, which considers a range of factors, including access to education. But the Peace Corps asked Claborne to assemble materials about return on investment, which he assumed were passed on to Scott. The Senator declared himself unsatisfied, and the Peace Corps never responded&nbsp;publicly.</p> \n    <p>The director, Olsen, had a long history with the agency, including time as a volunteer in Tunisia, in the nineteen-sixties. Some members of the Peace Corps community had feared that the Trump Administration would bring in an outsider to dismantle the agency, so Olsen’s appointment was greeted with relief. But, when the China program was attacked, Olsen stayed&nbsp;silent.</p> \n    <p>The pressure on the Peace Corps was connected to a growing anti-China sentiment. In some ways, it’s reminiscent of the era of “Farewell, Leighton Stuart!”—a frustration that China has not followed a path that Americans would prefer. Many China specialists are concerned that the <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> is overreacting. James Millward, a Georgetown University historian who is a vocal critic of China’s treatment of Uighurs, told me that he opposed cutting off the Peace Corps and other forms of engagement. He believes that the Magnitsky Act, which allows the <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> to sanction human-rights violators, should be applied to Chinese organizations and individuals who are active in the concentration camps. “It’s a measure that should be more directly associated with what is going on in Xinjiang, rather than keeping people from teaching English in Chengdu,” he&nbsp;said.</p> \n    <p>But the issue was settled quickly, behind closed doors. In November, the National Security Council held a meeting about Peace Corps China, chaired by Matthew Pottinger, the deputy national-security adviser. Pottinger is a former journalist in Beijing who subsequently joined the Marines, and he is known for his hawkish views on China. A senior official who served on the <span class=\"caps\">N.S.C.</span> during the Obama Administration told me that it’s unheard of for a deputy-level meeting to be held about a specific volunteer program. Peace Corps China cost $4.2 million in 2018, less than the State Department spent on the International Pacific Halibut Commission. “If you are deputy national-security adviser, you should have much more important issues on your plate,” the official said. “Think about what’s happening in November. Shouldn’t he be meeting on&nbsp;Iran?”</p> \n    <p>The following month, Olsen submitted a letter to the Office of Management and Budget announcing that Peace Corps China would be closed. Olsen’s letter noted that budgetary funds would be freed up for use in other places, mentioning three possible sites that don’t currently have volunteers: the Solomon Islands, Vietnam, and Greenland. There has been speculation that these countries were named in order to appeal to various geopolitical interests within the Administration. The Solomon Islands would satisfy those hoping to counter China’s influence in the Pacific, and a new program in Vietnam would fulfill the old idea of battling Communism. And Greenland because—well, because&nbsp;Greenland.</p> \n    <p>The day that the closure was announced, I had dinner with one of the Peace Corps’s Chinese staff members. The government no longer assigned people to these positions, and many of the thirty-plus staffers had applied hoping for better relations between China and the United States. They had largely given up the opportunity for social-security benefits in order to work for the American agency, whose status meant that some staff had difficulty applying for mortgages and credit cards. The woman I dined with asked me not to use her name, because the Peace Corps hadn’t yet negotiated severance&nbsp;packages.</p> \n    <p>The agency had informed staff and volunteers that China would be “graduating”—it was now so developed that it no longer needed Peace Corps teachers. But, the woman asked me, “if that was the case, why were they trying to expand so recently?” She added, “It’s like a divorce by one side,” noting that the news came less than a week before the lunar New Year holiday. Back in the U.S., the Peace Corps had already invited scores of new volunteers to serve in the next China cohort; now those applicants had to be reassigned. Helen Lowman, a former Peace Corps regional director who organized the graduation of programs in Romania and Bulgaria in the past decade, told me that she had never heard of such an abrupt and chaotic decision to phase out a country. “I probably talked to the host-country government for three years before we actually closed,” she&nbsp;said.</p> \n    <p>After dinner with the staff member, I met some volunteers at a hip bar called Commune. Such Communist chic wasn’t part of the Chengdu landscape when I served, although other things remained recognizable as the Peace Corps experience. A couple of volunteers quietly brought their own beer in bags. For China 25, the monthly stipend was less than three hundred&nbsp;dollars.</p> \n    <p>An African-American woman named Khloe Benton told me that she had been posted to a site in Gansu that had few foreign residents. “It’s been hard,” she said. “People follow me around, and they say things.” But she believed that it was important for locals to meet a person of color. The Peace Corps had told volunteers that they would finish out their terms, and they tried to cheer one another&nbsp;up.</p> \n    <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>You know why they lied to us,” another woman said, referring to the political pressure. “They didn’t have a&nbsp;choice.”</p> \n    <p>Eleven days later, the coronavirus caused the evacuation of all China volunteers. The same thing had happened with sars, in 2003, but the Peace Corps had returned the following year. This time, the program was finished—the last micro-history belonged to China 25. The volunteers had spent a little more than six months in the&nbsp;country.</p> \n    <p>One official in the State Department told me there were rumors that the White House had threatened the Peace Corps with budget cuts if it didn’t end the China program. When I asked Rick Scott, he said that he didn’t know how the Administration had made the decision, although he described his meetings with Jody Olsen and other Peace Corps officials. “I said, ‘What I’ve been told is that the volunteers who are there, they don’t coördinate anything with the State Department, they don’t promote American values, they don’t promote capitalism,’ ” Scott said. I asked if he had received the materials about return on investment, and whether they included such information as the number of volunteers who became&nbsp;diplomats.</p> \n    <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>I asked the Peace Corps about that,” Scott said. “They didn’t know of one person who had ever gone to the State Department from the Peace&nbsp;Corps.”</p> \n    <p>I said that twenty-seven former China volunteers now work in the State Department, and asked if this knowledge might have changed his mind. “I’d have to get more information,” he said, adding that the Peace Corps hadn’t been forthcoming. I had no way of checking this, because the Peace Corps and Olsen ignored multiple requests for an&nbsp;interview.</p> \n    <p>It occurred to me that this would have been a good follow-up lesson to our Fuling lectures about American democracy. In the nineties, we had known that the Chinese could cancel the program at any time. It had seemed a small miracle that local colleges were somehow able to communicate to high-level conservatives that Peace Corps teachers were worth the&nbsp;risk.</p> \n    <p>A woman speaks in front of cameras on a romantic reality <span class=\"caps\">TV</span> show. “These days, it’s nearly impossible to meet a hot sociopath the old-fashioned way.” Cartoon by Emily Bernstein Twenty years later, though, the Americans had discussed nothing openly, and Peace Corps administrators must have been either so frightened or so incompetent that they hadn’t defended themselves. The ideas that inspired “The Ugly American”—the importance of grassroots and local knowledge—had been abandoned. During our conversation, Scott acknowledged that he and his staff had not spoken with any current or former China&nbsp;volunteers.</p> \n    <p>The old confidence had also vanished. It seemed part of a larger American trend: every foreign contact was a threat, every exchange was zero-sum. Instead of trusting themselves and their best models, people regressed to the paranoia of those with closed systems. In the Washington Examiner, a conservative magazine, Tom Rogan celebrated the end of Peace Corps China. When Rogan mentioned the Chinese Ministry of State Security, he probably had no idea how much he sounded like a ministry&nbsp;hack:</p> \n    <p>We must thus ask how many of the more than 1,300 previous volunteers in China may have been recruited by the <span class=\"caps\">MSS</span> during their time there. The number is likely very small, but unlikely to be zero. How many of those volunteers then returned home to take up employment in the State Department or another <span class=\"caps\">U.S.</span> government&nbsp;agency?</p> \n    <p>In January, I visited Fuling with my family, and one afternoon we went to the former campus. It had been abandoned after the expanded college opened, up the Yangtze. Last year, developers started tearing down the old campus in order to construct high-rise&nbsp;apartments.</p> \n    <p>The classroom building was already gone, but my former apartment still stood. The library was also intact, although its doors were chained shut and many windows were broken. In front of the ruined building, a faded red banner proclaimed another tone-deaf&nbsp;slogan:</p> \n    <p>Build Nationwide Civilized City and National Hygienic&nbsp;Area</p> \n    <p>I Am Aware, I Participate, I Support, I Am&nbsp;Satisfied</p> \n    <p>While we were there, a man called out my Chinese name. He introduced himself as a former colleague who was also visiting the campus before it was demolished. Suddenly, I recognized him—in the old days, he sometimes came to my apartment late at night to borrow banned books. In front of the shuttered library, he said, “I remember reading about the Cultural Revolution.” I asked if the authorities had warned him about associating with the Americans, and he smiled shyly. “It wasn’t that direct,” he said. “But we were&nbsp;careful.”</p> \n    <p>I hadn’t known him or his colleagues as well as I knew our students. In my first book, I mentioned the surreptitious visits from the man and a few others. I described them as “shadowy figures who seemed to be groping for something that couldn’t be found in&nbsp;Fuling.”</p> \n    <p>Twenty years later, much remained in the shadows. I didn’t know what the teacher had gained from the banned books, or how my students were changed by our classes. But, as time passed, I was impressed by how much people remembered. “We were all poor at that time, we were eager to learn,” a student named Andi wrote recently, mentioning some school supplies that Adam had loaned her class. The accumulation of these small moments added up to something larger, but it wasn’t a formal accounting. That was a teacher’s confidence—confidence in his material, but also confidence in his students. They could make their own decisions about how they applied their&nbsp;lessons.</p> \n    <p>One evening, I spoke by telephone with Gabriel Exposito, a twenty-two-year-old who was among the last people to receive invitations to Peace Corps China. Exposito grew up in Havana, where one of his school memories involved a visit by a group of Americans. The children were instructed to avoid the foreigners, who made a donation that was spirited away by Communist officials. Exposito’s father eventually fled to Florida, where he found work as a nurse. He brought his son over from Cuba at the age of eleven. Exposito graduated cum laude from Florida State University, and when he applied to the Peace Corps he requested&nbsp;China.</p> \n    <p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>I know what a Communist education is like,” Exposito told me. “I was the student who wasn’t allowed to ask the hard questions. I saw the foreigners and couldn’t interact with them. I wanted to be on the other side of&nbsp;that.”</p> \n    <p>He was shocked to learn by tweet of the China program’s closure, and as a Floridian he called the offices of Senators Rubio and Scott to complain. He told staffers, “I agree with you—the Communist Party is a hostile entity. But we are breaking down the image they build of the American&nbsp;people.”</p> \n    <p>He requested a reassignment to a former Communist state, and the Peace Corps offered Mongolia, the Kyrgyz Republic, and Moldova. Exposito chose Moldova. “I thought, This is a former Soviet republic that’s next to Ukraine,” he said. “It’s an area that’s often forgotten about.” He had started studying Russian, and he hoped to eventually become either a scholar or a diplomat; I wished him the best of luck. He would have been perfect for China 26.&nbsp;♦</p> \n    <hr> \n     <h2 id=\"_6\">所以<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/ann-murmur-farewell-peace-corps.html#_6\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n     <div class=\"highlight\"> \n      <pre><span class=\"err\">但行好事</span>\n<span class=\"err\">莫问前程</span>\n<span class=\"err\">好好学习</span>\n<span class=\"err\">天天向上</span>\n</pre> \n     </div> \n     <p>这儿的 <code>好</code>, 是四声,&nbsp;自己喜欢的事儿.</p> \n     <p>什么是不惑?</p> \n     <blockquote> \n      <p>从心所欲不逾距</p> \n     </blockquote> \n     <p>也就是说, 将欲望本身进行 hacking ,&nbsp;从源头清除可能触发和谐的念头.</p> \n     <p>那么,&nbsp;具体怎么作呢?</p> \n     <p>这是另外一个系列的嗯哼了…</p> \n     <hr> \n      <h2 id=\"refer\">refer.<a class=\"headerlink\" \n</hr>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 11 Mar 2020 11:42:00 +0000","feedId":2079,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"56e45c182d1aed8c9899692412747609","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"ZoomQuiet","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598281148751},{"createdTime":"2020-08-24 22:59:08","updatedTime":"2020-08-24 22:59:08","title":"GC4S19E51🐙/ as the writer","link":"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170613-GC4S19E51-as-wirter.html","description":"<h1 id=\"gc4s19e51-as-the-writer\"><span class=\"caps\">GC4S19E51</span>🐙 as the writer<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170613-GC4S19E51-as-wirter.html#gc4s19e51-as-the-writer\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h1> \n<blockquote> \n <p>当写作成为能源时…</p> \n</blockquote> \n<h2 id=\"_1\">坏塌<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170613-GC4S19E51-as-wirter.html#_1\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>丫的,李雷发明的 <code>代笔机</code> 坏了, 收了我10个鸡腿的饭票,&nbsp;在我终于需要给出份儿情书时,却拿不出一篇能读的.</p> \n<p>我怒问:”怎么回事儿哪? 行不行哪…” “上周就知道有问题了, 只是没空修理而已.” “赶紧的, 下周就光棍节了” “好的,好的, 要不一起去修理吧, 最近用电量番了四倍,文章质量却不稳定了.”&nbsp;“行,反正现在就这事儿算个事儿….”</p> \n<p>一没留神,&nbsp;就和雷同学站在上百米高的岩洞里了,</p> \n<p>我很蒙:”呃…我们在哪儿?!” 李雷象看白痴一样:”你不是要一起来修理 代笔机 嘛? 其实是个缩微宇宙, 先对上千万颗行星进行自动进化, 从中选出来历史流向最象地球的这一颗, 只要表演点神迹, 灌输写作是唯一的生命真理, 然后引导他们向 文曲星神 献祭好文章,就能获得能源, 这样,我们就能持续获得无数体裁的文章, 再简单的过滤分类一下,&nbsp;就能随时提供命题文章了.”</p> \n<p>我大惊:”嗯哼? 你这是奴役, 奴役整个星球…” “乱说,明明是相互协作, 他们一样有生老病死,和我们没有什么不同.”&nbsp;“那只是奴役步骤多了几个阶段而已…”</p> \n<p>争吵中,我和雷同学稍微伪装了一下(戴上绿色的耳朵),&nbsp;乘正方体的漂浮船,假装从太空降落到中心广场.</p> \n<p>雷同学提醒:”注意,跟着我, 大拇指向下表示高兴, 当然,&nbsp;这是我乱教他们的…”</p> \n<p>长的象紫皮变色龙的当地智慧生物们兴高采烈的聚集了过来,</p> \n<p>其中最肥的那只,上前迎接我们:”敬爱的代理人, 很高兴你又从 星神 来访了” “尊敬的总总统阁下, 为什么你们献祭的文章突然没有感情了? 星神 很不满意.” “不应该哪, 能源一直很稳定,说明神很满意, 大家都开始尝试追求其它意义了.” “等等, 那文章谁还在写?” “哦, 那是我们伟大的科学家发明的 写作机 在自动进行了” “什么?&nbsp;带我们去看看…”</p> \n<h2 id=\"_2\">原因<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170613-GC4S19E51-as-wirter.html#_2\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>来到能源中心高塔顶部, 那位异常干瘦的非常鄙视这肥的: “总总统, 我反复解释过, 可是你根本没有理解的智能哪” “呃, 卫理思, 这次是给文曲星神&nbsp;的两位代理人来说明”</p> \n<p>雷同学等不及, 直接问:”等等, 你为什么要研究这种机器, 学校里难道没有教, 写作是唯一的真理嘛?” “我没上过学, 都是自己想的, 所以,&nbsp;没有人理解我作的事有多么伟大.”</p> \n<p><span class=\"dquo\">“</span>好吧, 你解释一下这个机器的原理吧.” “很简单, 我只是制造了个缩微宇宙, 然后加速进化, 从中选择一颗有合适智能生物的行星, 只要向它们灌输写作是唯一的使命, 献祭文章,就能获得能源, 我就能持续获得无数体裁的文章, 再简单的过滤就能从 星神 那儿换取能源了.&nbsp;只要返还小部分能源回去就好”</p> \n<p>雷同学暴怒:”你这是奴役! 无耻的奴役…” “怎么会, 只是平等的协作而已, 但是最近提交的文章没变, 不知道怎么的电量加倍了,&nbsp;要不我们一起去看看?”</p> \n<p>依然一闪神, 就和两位习惯制造奴役的家伙,再次传送到又一级缩微宇宙, 雷同学看不惯 卫理思 的一切行为:”至于嘛, 伪装外星人,还要穿上整个儿假皮肤…” “呵呵,我自己的小爱好, 对了, 过一会儿, 记得, 大拇指向上表示 高兴哪,&nbsp;是我乱教他们的…”</p> \n<p>我:”嚓…”&nbsp;我同学:”嚓…”</p> \n<p>又是一顿似曾相识无法纠结各种细节的欢迎仪式, 星球总督介绍了唯一的科学家:&nbsp;唐金,</p> \n<p>我们仨儿,默默看着他演示怎么制造缩微宇宙,&nbsp;并准备如何进行智能诱导…并热情的带我们下去视察,</p> \n<p>再再次传送到次次次级缩微宇宙后, 相同的对话,重新在 唐金和卫理思 间重复进行, 突然, 卫理思 终于反应过来, 暴怒的冲向雷同学: “你竟然创造了我们的宇宙, 只是为了骗我们写作?” 于是,他俩热情的撕打起来, 好在都算科学家, 体力很儿童,&nbsp;一时不会有事,</p> \n<p>我也愿意看到这俩个混蛋受点儿教训,就没有上去拉架.</p> \n<p>唐金 站在一边, 听了会俩人的对话, 也反应过来了: “你们创造了他的宇宙? 他创造了我们的宇宙?&nbsp;都只是为了写作?”</p> \n<p>我只有苦笑: “是的, 你理解正确” “折腾这么多年, 还四处求来写作教程, 准备给这里的原始生物教授 好中文写作课… 原来只是….&nbsp;哈哈哈哈哈哈哈哈…”</p> \n<p>唐金 崩溃了,驾驶着浮空器, 撞山自杀,&nbsp;这下我们仨都傻眼了…</p> \n<h2 id=\"_3\">解决<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170613-GC4S19E51-as-wirter.html#_3\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<p>幸好, 缩微宇宙的时间流动也是和空间级别相同缩微的… 我们仨用了4年,才从次次次级宇宙逐层蜕升上来, 我们俩又用了4个月,才摆脱了卫理思&nbsp;的追杀回到地球宇宙.</p> \n<p>不过, 代笔机 居然就这么恢复正常了,&nbsp;用电量也恢复了原先的水平.</p> \n<p>我不解,雷同学说:”卫理思 好歹是名科学家, 逻辑上很明智, 无论他怎么折腾,&nbsp;对于我只有两种选择:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>丢掉现在的宇宙,重新构建</li> \n <li>继续使用现有宇宙</li> \n</ol> \n<p>所以,&nbsp;他作出了合理的选择…”</p> \n<p>我却不由总在想,&nbsp;这个宇宙真正的目的真心是什么?</p> \n<h2 id=\"_4\">是也乎<a class=\"headerlink\" href=\"https://blog.zoomquiet.io/170613-GC4S19E51-as-wirter.html#_4\" title=\"Permanent link\">¶</a></h2> \n<ul> \n <li>170609 Rick and Morty&nbsp;那一集..</li> \n <li>170610 嗯哼到 writer…&nbsp;梗儿</li> \n <li>170611&nbsp;1小时完成初稿</li> \n <li>170611 小组内怼后,&nbsp;20分钟,自捋一次</li> \n</ul>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 13 Jun 2017 12:42:00
